name: curcumin Curcumin
description: Curcumin is an additive added to foods as a yellow-orange colorant. It is the active substance in the spice turmeric (Curcuma longa). A plant from the ginger family, originating from South Asia. It is cultivated in India, Indonesia, and China. There it is mostly used as a spice (ground root), and also as a dye for fabric, as it gives a yellow pigment.
function: Additive added to foods as a yellow-orange colorant.
origin: Plant from the ginger family, originating from South Asia. Cultivated in India, Indonesia, and China.
healthRisks: In recommended doses, it is not problematic, but it is not recommended for people with gallstones, jaundice, colic, and liver poisoning. It is also not advisable to take it in larger quantities, as it can cause nausea and migraines. Exceptionally, it can pose a health risk (allergy or food sensitivity). In any case, it is necessary to consider that there is a big difference between curcumin obtained from the plant and that which is synthetically obtained.
usage: Added to foods as a yellow-orange colorant. Used as a spice (ground root), and also as a dye for fabric, as it gives a yellow pigment.

name: riboflavin 5'-phosphate (Riboflavin-5'-Phosphate)
adi: 0.500 mg/kg body weight/day (JECFA, 1998) not limited or determined (EFSA, 2013).

name: tartrazin (Tartrazine)
description: Banned in Norway and Austria. Gradually being phased out; products containing this additive must be specially labeled in the EU.
healthRisks: Reports of triggering asthmatic attacks, hives (urticaria) in children (incidence 1:10,000); suspected link to thyroid tumors, chromosome damage, hyperactivity; hypersensitivity reactions when used with aspirin.

name: sunset yellow FCF Sunset Yellow FCF
description: Banned in Norway, Finland, and the United Kingdom. Can cause hives (urticaria), chronic runny nose, stuffy nose, allergies, hyperactivity, kidney tumors, chromosome damage, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, digestive disorders, loss of appetite; proven higher incidence of tumors in animals. It is slowly being phased out, and products with this additive will have to be specially labeled in the EU from now on.
healthRisks: Can cause hives (urticaria), chronic runny nose, stuffy nose, allergies, hyperactivity, kidney tumors, chromosome damage, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, digestive disorders, loss of appetite; proven higher incidence of tumors in animals.
otherDetails: Banned in Norway, Finland, and the United Kingdom. It is slowly being phased out, and products with this additive will have to be specially labeled in the EU from now on.

name: azorubin (Azorubine)
description: Banned in Canada, Japan, Norway, Sweden, Austria, and the USA.
healthRisks: Reactions in asthmatics and people allergic to aspirin, hyperactivity in children, proven higher incidence of tumors in animals.
otherDetails: Products containing this additive must be specially labeled in the EU. Gradually being phased out.

name: butylated hydroxyanisole (Butylated hydroxyanisole)
description: Butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA) is an antioxidant obtained by the reaction of 4-methoxyphenol and isobutylene.
function: It inhibits oxidation and the development of unpleasant odors, used as a preservative.
healthRisks: The US National Institutes of Health report carcinogenicity in test animals, especially in large doses. The recommended daily dose up to 0.5 mg/kg body weight is considered much too low by some to cause cancer, but by others, e.g., the state of California, the substance is carcinogenic. It can cause allergic reactions, hyperactivity or other reactions (twitching). Not recommended for children, as the group for supporting children's hyperactivity strongly advocates discontinuing the additive due to its impact on hyperactive behavioral disorders in children. In combination with high vitamin C content, free radicals can be produced that damage cells, including DNA. This has prompted many discussions in the EU and in the ANS additives committee to initiate additional studies on harmfulness and limit the use of BHA.
usage: Added to edible oils, fats, margarines, chewing gums, candies, nuts, and generally foods with high fat content (e.g., in quick-prepare potato products and bakery products, because it is stable at high temperatures such as in biscuits, cakes, pastries).
adi: Up to 0.5 mg/kg body weight
otherDetails: Used in food and its packaging, animal feed, cosmetics, rubber products, petroleum derivatives, and medicines. Added to edible oils, fats, margarines, chewing gums, candies, nuts, and high-fat foods since the mid-20th century. Banned in Japan since 1958. Recommended for withdrawal in Great Britain but this was abandoned. McDonald's had to discontinue use in its products in the USA in 1986. Banned in infant nutrition.

name: butylated hydroxytoluene (Butylated hydroxytoluene)
adi: 0.050 mg/kg body weight/day (SCF, 1987); 0.300 mg/kg body weight/day (JECFA, 1996); 0.250 mg/kg body weight/day (EFSA, 2012)

name: lecithin (sunflower) (Lecithin (sunflower))
description: Lecithin is obtained mainly from soy beans, egg yolk, milk, marine sources, oilseed rape, cotton, and sunflower. It is an excellent emulsifier and stabilizer in water-oil/fat mixtures. It is also sold as a dietary supplement or for medical purposes. Sunflower lecithin obtained from sunflower seeds does not pose a health risk.
function: Emulsifier and stabilizer in mixtures of water-oil/fat.
origin: Mainly from soy beans, egg yolk, milk, marine sources, oilseed rape, cotton, and sunflower (specifically sunflower lecithin from sunflower seeds).
healthRisks: Can pose a health risk because over 90% of soy worldwide is genetically modified. In larger quantities, it can cause stomach issues. Sunflower lecithin does not represent a health risk.
usage: Used in many products - confectionery (chocolates, biscuits, ice creams, chewing gums, spreads, flakes), in baking various products, in bread and pastries, pasta, margarine, mayonnaise, etc.
otherDetails: Sold also as a dietary supplement or for medical purposes.
